results.title: Corporate Globalisation
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A look at the negative effects of corporate globalization has on the environment and human rights laws. Screened as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Campaspe
results.brief_description: Nine stories about residents from around the Campaspe region in northern Victoria. Covering the towns of Nanneella, Gunbower and Colbinabbin, locals tell stories about their lives and their connection to the land and the community.

results.title: The Lunar cycle
results.creator_credit: Academy of Interactive Entertainment (AIE) and Kai Faigenbaum
results.brief_description:
A man on a unicycle travels above the sleeping city on a cloudy night, sweeping darkness away to reveal a new moon. This 3D animated fable offers a new interpretation of the term ‘lunar cycle’.
Music by Andy Statman.

results.title: The Capitol
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Capitol Theatre plays a vital part in the social life of Warrnambool. Built in 1929 and opened in 1930, in 2008 the cinema has been converted into three separate cinemas, run by General Manager, Greg Gent. Taking us on a tour of the historic cinema, Gent discusses the challenges of running a cinema in the DVD age.
Stan and Norma Stevens have been associated with the cinema for over 50 years where Stan first worked as an usher and the cinema was the setting for their first date. Noel Hallam worked at the theatre for 34 years and Ivan Berndt has been the projectionist for 37 years. Each has their own stories to tell on how the theatre has been an integral part of their lives and how it continues to be.

results.title: Absolutely fabulous
results.creator_credit: Bob Spiers, Jon Plowman and BBC
results.brief_description: Absolutely fabulous is one of the most successful British comedy shows; an hilarious situation comedy that plays with elements of the absurd and high camp. Edwina (Jennifer Saunders) is a baby-boomer mother, fashion victim extraordinaire. Her best friend is the cocaine-snorting nymphomaniac Patsy (Joanna Lumley). Part of the show’s success comes from its reversal of roles. It is the practical long-suffering Saffie, Edwina’s daughter, who sweeps up after her mother, and the in-your-face portrayal of drug-taking, sex-loving, materialistic women who are spoilt, selfish, vacuous but undeniably good fun. Always colourful, often brilliant, “Absolutely fabulous” confirmed Saunders and co-writer Dawn French as two of the best comedians of their generation.

results.title: The Lorne Theatre
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Established over 90 years ago, the Lorne Theatre came about when a travelling picture show man ran out of funds and some local business men purchased his equipment and started running movies in the local hall. It then moved to its present site in 1937, where for such a small permanent population, the theatre has not changed much in all those years. Tony Hill, Manager of the Lorne Theatre, talks about the difficulties in offering a diverse range of cinema in the climate of DVDs and downloadable movies, and operating in a town prone to blackouts. He is proud the theatre is attended by a local group of cinephiles who sit in the same seat every session, and thinks himself very lucky to have his job.
